Update the Dispersion (Scale) Parameter for GLMs

Source: R/utils.R
update_dispersion.Rd

Estimate the dispersion (scale) parameter for two-parameter GLM families (Gaussian, Gamma, inverse Gaussian) using either Pearson or deviance residuals. For one-parameter families (binomial, Poisson) and Cox, the dispersion remains 1.

update_dispersion(y, family = gaussian(), offset = 0, approach = "pearson")

Arguments

y

Numeric vector of responses. For Cox models, supply the event times (first column) if family$family == "cox".

family

A stats::family object (e.g. gaussian(), Gamma(), inverse.gaussian()). Must include linkinv and variance methods, and—if approach = "deviance"—a dev.resids method.

offset

Numeric scalar or vector of linear predictors. If scalar, recycled to length length(y) before applying the inverse link to compute \(\mu\).

approach

Character string, either "pearson" (default) to use Pearson residuals, or "deviance" to use deviance residuals.

Value

Numeric scalar giving the estimated dispersion:

Gaussian, Gamma, inverse Gaussian

Moment‐based estimate

Binomial, Poisson, Cox

Always 1

Details

The Pearson estimate is $$\hat{\phi} = \frac{\sum_i (y_i - \mu_i)^2 / V(\mu_i)}{n - p},$$ and the deviance estimate is $$\hat{\phi} = \frac{\sum_i d_i}{n - p},$$ where \(d_i\) are the deviance residuals returned by family\$dev.resids\((y, \mu, wt)\). Here, \(p\) is the number of estimated parameters (intercept + slopes); for a univariate slope-only model, one may set \(p = 1\), but by default we use \(p = 0\) when only updating dispersion.

Examples

# \donttest{
# Gaussian with known offset
y <- rnorm(100, mean = 2)
off <- rep(1, 100)
update_dispersion(y, gaussian(), offset = off, approach = "pearson")
#> [1] 2.542464

# Gamma model
y <- rgamma(100, shape = 2, scale = 3)
off <- rep(0, 100)
update_dispersion(y, Gamma(link = "log"), offset = off, approach = "deviance")
#> [1] 7.114632

# Poisson (dispersion fixed at 1)
y <- rpois(100, lambda = 5)
update_dispersion(y, poisson(), offset = 0)
#> [1] 21.59
# }
